nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction can improve machine learning performance in hyperspectral optical imaging for soil moisture estimation while preserving strong predictive capability
The hyperspectral dataset contains 679 samples with soil moisture targets and 125 spectral bands covering 450-950 nm collected from a bare-soil field campaign
All spectral features were standardized and experiments used fixed random states for reproducibility; data split was train/test with test size 0.3
PCA was applied to the standardized 125-band feature matrix and components were selected to retain more than 99 percent of total variance
A Random Forest regression model with 100 trees was trained on the PCA-transformed features and evaluated using the R2 score
PCA reduced data dimensionality to two principal components (PC1 and PC2) which together explain over 99 percent of variance
Dataset was acquired with a Cubert UHD 285 snapshot camera (50x50 pixels, 125 contiguous bands, approx 4 nm resolution) and ground truth by TRIME-PICO TDR
The soil moisture target values span approximately 25 to 43 percent and are moderately concentrated near 32 percent
Train and test splits produced closely aligned soil moisture distributions, supporting reliable supervised evaluation
Covariance analysis, eigenvalue distribution, and scree plot show a sharp decay after PC2, validating selection of two components
StandardScaler and sklearn.decomposition.PCA implementations were used to produce the reduced representation
Random Forest trained on PCA-transformed data achieved R2 = 0.947, indicating about 94.7 percent of soil moisture variance explained
Projection onto PC1 and PC2 reveals clearer separation of samples by soil moisture, demonstrating that the reduced representation preserves discriminatory information
PCA reduces spectral redundancy and computational complexity while retaining key predictive information, enabling more interpretable and scalable ML workflows
Limitations include use of a single dataset from one field campaign and evaluation limited to PCA and Random Forest; further work should test other feature extraction methods and diverse sensors
